definition: **A peroxisome** is a small, single-membrane organelle containing enzymes that catalyze <u>oxidative reactions</u>. Peroxisomes break down <u>fatty acids</u> and amino acids and neutralize toxic compounds (producing hydrogen peroxide, H2O2, as a byproduct, which is then broken down by the enzyme <u>catalase</u>).
tips: Peroxisomes perform **<u>beta-oxidation</u>** of long-chain fatty acids, generating acetyl-CoA that can be repurposed by the cell.
They contain **<u>catalase</u>**, an enzyme that decomposes hydrogen peroxide into water and oxygen - this protects the cell from oxidative damage due to H2O2 buildup (hence the organelle's name).
Unlike lysosomes, which are formed in the Golgi apparatus, peroxisomes can <u>self-replicate</u> (bud and divide) and are not part of the endomembrane system.
exam_appearance: If a question mentions breakdown of very-long-chain fatty acids or detoxification of alcohol in cells (especially liver cells) -> think **<u>peroxisomes</u>** (these organelles oxidize fatty acids and neutralize ethanol).

Concept trap -> **Peroxisomes vs. Lysosomes**: peroxisomes carry out <u>oxidation reactions</u> using molecular oxygen (producing H2O2 and then degrading it), whereas lysosomes use <u>acid hydrolases</u> to digest biomaterials. Be sure to distinguish these on exams.

Genetic tie-in: Disorders like <u>Zellweger syndrome</u> (a peroxisome biogenesis disorder) illustrate peroxisome importance - cells lacking functional peroxisomes accumulate long-chain fatty acids and other toxins, leading to severe developmental issues.
